block.p: The tortured history of the life and destruction of Germany's Jews was on display as prominent politicians and cultural figures turned out for the opening of the Jewish Museum in Berlin, a building so symbolic and emotionally disorienting as to overshadow the exhibit it houses. The opening brought President Johannes Rau, Chancellor Gerhard Schröder and many others to what had become an unmissable event, a bizarre, redemptive mixture of social need and societal sorrow so compelling that it seemed to encapsulate Germany's paradoxes.
